author: incomeproject
title: Universal Basic Income DAO
description: Legacy financial and identity infrastructure is too difficult to navigate, expensive, and censorable for us to provide a truly global UBI.

f6_assessments.q0: This is crushing since I absolutely love this idea however the proposer does not adequately address the criteria of the challenge in any of the sections.  The proposal does identify the challenge of providing a means to support a living wage and the conceptual thought on how to achieve this seems reasonable however the proposer needs to provide a plan which clearly identifies a successful path and the team/resources which can achieve success.  The proposal has too many unanswered questions such as will tax donations work? Is the volunteer DevOps capable? How the NFT approach will work? I think with additional expertise this proposal could be successful in another Fund.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer has provided an outline of the major steps however this should be provided in a roadmpa associated with a specific timeline (ie Month 1 – build website domain, design receipt NFT, Month 2 – identify stake pools, etc.).  By creating a specific timeline the proposer can associate KPIs.  Considering the scope of the project I am not confident the team is sufficient enough to successfully complete.  I would suggest reducing the funding request to get a portion of the project built first (e.g. design receipt NFT) to demonstrate success or to engage an experienced team willing to provide a services on a volunteer basis or low cost.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer has not provided enough details on trackable KPIs along with a method in which those KPIs will be communicated.  I would suggest to the proposer to build a roadmap with a timeline and then align KPIs (e.g. Month 1 - design receipt NFT with KPI of receipt NFT in a transaction or viewable, Month 1 – build website with KPI users can view website.

f6_assessments.q0: Project aims to provide eventually provide universal basic income to as many people as possible, starting with the lower income. It is funded much like an endowment which means it’s going to take a lot of money to make it happen. Let’s say the goal is to initially provide $12,000 a year per person that increases gradually to keep up with inflation, an average return of 7%, of which 5% will be distributed and 2% reinvested. That would mean $240,000 in the endowment fund to provide basic income to one person to onboard to Cardano and this proposal is only requesting for $50,000. While it is a noble goal, perhaps this might not be the best way forward. Just a thought, but having come across Harmony’s ZKDAO where they provide a decentralized basic income to developers who meet certain growth milestones for their product and number of users, this might be a better way to onboard more people to Cardano via basic income. The wealth generated by all those developers who are able to keep churning out products that attracts lots of users might actually be a faster way to a truly universal basic income.
f6_assessments.q1: Both team members seem to have the experience required to build it out, having worked at Google and DoorDash for years. They have also set up a non-profit and will dedicate the funds to their endowment fund to provide universal basic income. Both of them seem to have the heart and the skills.
f6_assessments.q2: Their work will be open source on github. Milestones can be easily audited such as amount of funds donated to the DAO, and disbursement of basic incomes via a decentralized identity. What might be harder is proving to the community that the money reached their intended audience.

f6_assessments.q0:
From the identified problem and the provided solution to solve the problem it is difficult to understand what is the need of a blockchain for this UBI model, generally speaking, and Cardano Blockchain in particularly. In theory the UBI model is for every person from a community (country, county, village level) and not for a part of it as it will look more like an annuity, thus making it subjective for its mission.
Also the proposal doesn't fit into the Challenge brief as it fails to comply with the guidelines. ("What needs do users of Cardano have that could be solved by new applications?" is one of it)

The proposal seems that is not able to scale and to address future challenges. (this type of activity needs continuous funding and more and more people will want to be a part of this. Due to the high volatility of the crypto market how a guaranteed living wage will be assured when the price of an asset, related to FIAT currencies, will plunge by 100%?).
f6_assessments.q1:
It seems that the team members have some technical background (SW development) that could help them to implement this proposal. It is recommended to provide some useful references about past successfully implemented projects for better auditability.

The requested budget is not broken down into identifiable items and it seems that the sum will be used as a donation as the working part is on a volunteer basis.

The proposal doesn't offer a realistic timetable to complete the work as there is no deadline for any deliverable. (how long does it take to complete one (or more) phase(s) of the project?)
f6_assessments.q2: Based on the provided info it is difficult to assess the progress of the proposal implementation. Due to the hight volatility of the cryptocurrency market there is a high risk that the funds necessary for those in need will diminish, from month to month ,thus being under the set threshold. This kind of financial model doesn't look too feasible.

f6_assessments.q0: This is a good idea because many are people that are living in bad financial conditions who would greatly benefit from this. The proposers have done a great job listing all the benefits that this project can add to the cardano ecosystem. However, as specified by the proposers, a huge challenge will be to implement an identity system that will allow them to pick the receivers of these funds. As they have mentioned, the DID is in its infancy and cannot be relied on. Altogether, the proposers have done a good job identifying the strengths and weaknesses of this project.
f6_assessments.q1: I don’t have high confidence in the implementation of this proposal. It seems that the proposers have not figured out the identity challenge. In fact they have to have a good system in place in order to select the funds receivers. I think that the proposers need to do more research on how to tackle this and understand the budget needed to implement this. Right now there is not a  budget breakdown. I recommend to the proposer to also add a timetable to complete the work. Altogether, I don’t see this project being implemented successfully as there is too much information missing. However the idea is great and I suggest to the proposer to do more research and come up with the best solution.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal is not autidable at the moment because it lacks the basic information to track its progress. There is no roadmap that we can check to follow the progress of the development of the project. I recommend to the proposers to add a roadmap with milestones and strong metrics/KPIs that define the success of the proposal. Other than that, this is a good idea that needs to be researched well.

f6_assessments.q0:
Even though the project acknowledges “we are quite literally paying them to do so” I see this initiative as having the potential of attracting a large number of users to Cardano. Not just those directly benefiting from the program, but way beyond that, as UBI, is a topic of interest to many people, and by coming in contact with the approach proposed, either by researching it or by word of mouth, they would inevitably come into contact with the blockchain.

The objectives and plans of the project are very clearly defined and are realistic, at least when it comes to this first stage. The main risk is successfully identified, and expectations are appropriately managed.
f6_assessments.q1:
The roadmap presented is very clear and I see no major obstacles in its successful implementation, especially given the experience presented by the team. The only thing I would have liked to see as an addition to the feasibility section of the proposal, are external links/references so that the claims made by the authors of the proposal about team bios and experience can be easily verified by the community.

Since the team plans to donate the requested amount to serve as the initial treasury of the DAO, no actual breakdown of the costs is needed, however, I would have liked to see a clearer emphasis of this point.
f6_assessments.q2:
The progress of the project will be easy to follow and verify by the Cardano community as the developers plan to open source their work and make it available on GitHub. Coupled with the other reporting methods outlined in the proposal, auditing should not constitute a problem at all.

The milestones presented as definitions of success are clear and verifying their implementation should be an easy task.

solution: Spin up a DAO to work in parallel to our legacy non-profit, systematically rolling out living wages to people on-chain.
experience: We are US-based 501(3)(c) non-profit focused on increasing economic empowerment by sustainably rolling out guaranteed living wages to everyone. Our team has experience engineering software in the for-good, startup, and FAANG spaces.
